comments.commentBody: Sadly, with Citizens United, money doesn't talk, it quietly screams.
"Money talks" is not the same as "Money is speech."

I chose the 6 smallest sweet potatoes I could find but after slicing, I had enough for 2 9-inch baking pans. I live in NC, perhaps our sweet potatoes are larger? Any other southerners to weigh in? Was the recipe intended for yams instead?
After finding I had way too many potatoes I doubled the amount of prunes and made two dishes. There was enough butter for both pans.
The flavors and final dish are excellent but the quantity of ingredients seems way off to me for just 1 dish.

Cooked this for Chrismas dinner. It was fantastic. Best roast I have ever had. Everyone loved it. Timing was perfect. Followed the recipe exactly except for substituting ground allspice (1tp) for the 6 berries.
Texas truly is a cruel and self righteous place.
Being the gracious recipient of a gift freely given is a beautiful thing.
No, it is not. We have many charitable groups here and participate vigorously in giving back to the community. Just bc one person is a Scrooge doesn't mean we all are.

Why, if the author was asking for God to help, that letters to Santa were written? I agree that it is wonderful that the children were able to have a lovely Christmas due to the love and generosity of friends, but asking Santa for toys doesn't seem to match the faith the author is raising her children to believe. (Comparing the porch lights to the stars of Bethlehem and then being handed a gift card for dinner certainly required a stretch of imagination for this reader)

Went with cajun seasoning rubbed in 2 days before Christmas and baked on Christmas morning.

The results were amazing. Even relatives who hate turkey were picking the bones apart.
Excellent. One  comment,warm the yogurt to room temperature before mixing in.

Not enough left for step 2.

This was excellent with cajun turkey instead of the standard cranberry chutney.

I've never watched this show, but I enjoy it more than I did this column.
Having spent a fair amount of time in Britain and having many British friends, I find that it exists and is different from other English-speaking countries. And I like the British people, be they from London, the North, Scotland, Northern Ireland, Wales, Jamaica, or Pakistan.

Justice Holmes:

Your worldview has individuals, banded together as corporations to make money or conduct other lawful business, as merely creatures of a state that actually holds ALL power and dispenses indulgences so long as they suit the ideological prejudices of whoever controls the levers of that power. I see individuals, whether they band together as corporations or act independently, as the legitimate source of ALL power, and attempts to minimize their power as acts of tyranny. We'll continue to vie over whose worldview gets to call the shots, but my side already has Congress, a large majority of Republican statehouses and a majority of governorships. At the federal level, all we need is a hat trick, and we're not far from getting it.

It's going to be interesting to see what happens to your rationalizations if Republicans are able to pull off undivided government, and now OUR premises become the active ones because we again hold the executive and control the agencies. No doubt, you'll kvetch no end that even more of the production of others that you regard as your "tax money" will be "stolen", and that the perpetrators will not only get away with it but laugh as they do it.

Montreal Moe:

eh? Wicked!

Republicans believe in building and maintaining infrastructure, defending ourselves and our allies against external threats of all kinds, policing ourselves effectively, and "providing for the general welfare", which certainly includes education and investments that benefit all, such as basic research; and we believe in a basic safety net for people who need temporary help to get back on their feet.

But most of us carry on an ancient and respected American tradition of regarding taxes as necessary evils to be tolerated only so far as a case is made for spending money on something collectively. Anything else frankly feeds a runaway government that never tires of finding uses for other people's money and uses your curious collectivist ideas as justification for taking it. And along that path lies the complete subsumption of the individual into the collective that we see in much of the world but, thankfully, not yet completely here.

Commenters here respond against an act by the Republican congressional majority that seeks to elevate the rights of individuals against the power of collectives that can be manipulated until individuals have no power at all. I support their action.

Richard, the Republican Party I knew and extolled those virtues is, as my people say of blessed memory.
Your GOP is a party of MOB rule, of might is right of Theocrats and Neocons. It is the totalitarian state of Orwell's 1984. It is the party of ther Ministry of Truth. The party you speak of died when America forgot its history and forgot that it was not to be a nation under God but was a nation under men. America was not to rely on prayer but personal responsibility to create a more perfect union.
For most thinking Americans politics today is about lesser evil-ism and in 2016 the Democrats are a far lesser evil.

It's a dark day indeed when Congress complicates the rise of another Lois Lerner, abusing power at the IRS, an agency that should be concerned with absolutely nothing else than collection of taxes. The basic problem is the taxation of earnings -- as soon as you resolve to do that, you open society to whatever predations government can hatch to identify every dime of earnings, down to Suzie's lemonade stand, and you empower the IRS to poke into absolutely every facet of our lives. It has been used again and again as a cudgel by whatever power holds the White House, but this small attempt by Congress to put a leash on a wild beast is pilloried by the editors.

Get used to a free exchange of ideas expressed loudly and, typically for Americans, sulphurously, since Citizens United made that possible; and the left might consider ways that they can compete effectively in this brave new world rather than constantly tossing sour grapes when they can't.

Then, the editors find MORE cause for carping in Congress's action to keep Democrats from targeting corporations for ruinous economic attacks when they have the monumental chutzpah to contribute to Republican campaigns. The entreaty will fall on deaf ears; but it might help attract such contributions if the left learned not to despise private enterprise and corporations. Opening up the lists of private corporate contributions won't happen.

"Dark Money": now THAT'S a hoot. What you wish to destroy you must first demonize.
I loved the "one getting an across-the-board promotion" clue.
I'm surprised that you believe it was the majority party that passed the bill.

@Louise: did you read the article?  Take a look: "In acting to seal that pocket and hobble the I.R.S., congressional Republicans are advancing what has become the dark age of plutocratic money in campaign spending."  While I'm sure some Democrats did vote for this, the Editorial Board makes it clear that it is the "Republican Congress" that is calling the shots--just about every paragraph says so.

You make statements such as the party which relies on should block any attempt to ....,,,,"
Prove it. You can't make a statement like that and not offer one factual example. I want to see unbiased data from Jonathan Turley, Ted Olsen and Alan Dershowitz

2 final points
1) Did the Supreme Court uphold DOMA? Did tha Court support gay marriage? 2 Why? Aren't they sinficant for impacting the rights of the gay community? Didn't they give gays far greater rights than they ever had?
2) The Court has issued 13. 9-0 decisions against Obama including the recessed appointments. Did Sotomayor and Kagan, 2 Obama appointees betray him by voting aginst Obama 13 times?

You constantly make emotional comments not based on fact Take the emotion out of it and make a fact based comment. You mock Republicans like me based inn a very deep hate that consumes you. Question Does writing these attacks against nameless, faceless Repunlicans like me change anything? . You may think you are better than me but you're not At least my every post is not an arrogant morally superior post. I use facts Try it sometime

Can anyone be surprised that as the year draws to a close, the majority party would vote in a Christmas stocking of special tax benefits?

Is it any wonder that the party which relies the most on dark money would block any attempt to make it less opaque?

This SCOTUS has done more damage to the equalizing structure of full tax and disclosure laws that any court in history. If anyone doubts that 2016 and the ability of either party to define the direction of this country for the next decades they are willingly blind.
Fun and easy for a Saturday, did not need to look anything up.

In hindsight, the cake was delicious. My earlier post of poorly measured flour still stands. However, I baked the cake MUCH longer (maybe an hour more) than originally noted. Patience paid off! The cake was most, dense and wildly flavorful with lots of crispy caramelized edges. In the future I will adjust the flour to the correct amount but this minor set back will not keep me from making this again. It's a winner!
ALL soups benefit from sitting and letting flavors develop.  (Homemade is ALWAYS the best!)  Thank you for the comment.

This recipe is bland. Sweat onions and the white part of leek before adding chicken stock (home made). Then add frozen peas. Cook for an hour!  Yes! Then use an immersion blender and leave in the fridge for 24 hours to let the flavours cure. Then it is delicious ☺

This cake is a WINNER! So easy and resulted in raves from dinner guests. I did increase the amount of clementines since mine were quite small and added a wee bit more almond flour so the batter had a little more heft. All went well with baking this and the chocolate glaze was perfect. Jus the right amount of chocolate!
h.

Made this curd exactly as described--Turned out beautifully and had a wonderful color! Also decorated it with some homemade candied cranberries. Lastly, didn't have access to any hazelnuts, so I used an Ida Gardner lemon curd tart recipe for the crust (flour, sugar, butter, vanilla) and baked two smaller, 7in tarts. I made it all ahead of time and baked it the day of (froze the crust and refrigerated the curd).

Guest LOVED it!

https://www.pinterest.com/pin/279293614369658545/
I like the recipe as is.  I just added a large carrot.

Delicious and unusual. The recipe is surprisingly light although quite rich. Definitely a keeper. Next time I will try a variation using at least double the rice and perhaps more cheese. It may not be soubise but I'm sure it will also be delicious.

Once you see their misleading ads with manipulated facts it's hard to trust them with their intention. The promotional campaign was built on misinformation and inaccurate data to help gather public support and misfired. If it was truly novel they wouldn't need to cook up facts like "92% indian women supports free basic". Hope India kicks out these self proclaimed charity workers trying to get rural India to poke each other and increase their stock valuation.
Aha -- I imagine it was the cover that did it.  Try it without the cover, and I think the soupiness problem will go away!
Made this yesterday for Christmas, and it seemed too soupy.  I baked the dish in a covered casserole, but I'm curious if others baked it uncovered.  Flavor was good.

When government policies and rules can be purchased, new and powerful scams become possible -- scams that can crash the whole economy and that unavoidably render it less economically efficient.  Financial deals and dealings cannot be the bedrock of a large nation's economy, but much of the money made in the past few decades is being made in this way.

If political activity is taxed and charitable activity isnt, some entity must decide and have ways to decide which is which, so the IRS can figure out who owes what. It is logical and efficient for the IRS itself to make this decision, but if we wanted we could create a separate Activity Classification Service to decide whether activity is political or not. Either would be staffed by civil servants and commanded by a political appointee.

If the expenditure of vast sums of money sways elections, then the winner is the one with the most money and the most competence and wisdom in spending it. What should sway elections, if democracy is to work, is the validity of candidate ideas and the ability of the candidates to get things done. Vast sums of money get in the way of this rather than helping.

There are three candidates who are introducing ideas not usually available for free exchange: Trump, Sanders, and Rand Paul. Two of them do not do what Citizens United made possible, and the third tries unsuccessfully. What Citizens United has made more and more widespread is a visceral dislike of establishment politicians, and this dislike undercuts the effectiveness of establishment-type campaigns and campaign tactics and promotes candidates who are perceived as not friendly to or respectful of the establishment and the ordinary ways of politics in this country.

Yum -- this was great, 120 degrees perfect for taking the beef out. Stuffing delicious. But next time, as well as wrapping the bone tips in foil, I'd also lay a strip of foil over the top of any exposed stuffing; that top edge was a little burnt. Not that we didn't gobble it up! But -- perhaps a useful tip.

Making IRS and SEC into a political football is not the way though. It starts with the SCOTUS and it should be ended by it. Saying President Obama should do all the heavy lifting simply obscure the issue.

This is not endorsing the right but at least it has followed through with the Citizen United lawsuit. Has the left done anything like that? People like Ralph Nader don't hesitate to call attention to themselves at the expense of others but in no instance they put their money where the mouth is. For goodness sake, same sex marriage was taken to the Supreme Court by none other than David Boies and Ted Olson, the two legal gunslingers.

So it NYT editorial wants to shame anyone into doing something, it should look what is really happening
I thought these were subtle, rather than "bland", as some cooks have thought; but certainly a bit less oil/butter would be fine, also less time in the oven -- 10 or 15 minutes plenty.
